channel.title: Math
channel.description:
Just some problems needed for everyday life ;)
Let a[sub]1[/sub], a[sub]2[/sub]... , be a sequence with the following properties.
Let a[sub]1[/sub] = 1 and a[sub]2n[/sub]= n * a[sub]n[/sub] for any positive integer [i]n[/i][/i]
What is the value of a[sub]2 100[/sub] Something like that, can't seem to get it.
Three mutually tangent spheres of radius 1 rest on a horizontal plane. A sphere of radius 2 rests on them.
What is the distance from the plane to the top of the larger sphere?
Help is appreciated ;)

item.title: Math
item.dc:creator: @_DEAD *DEAD*
item.description:
@_DEAD wrote:

man i must be really bored so ill answer your second question.
the first thing you have to do is figure out the point of each smaller sphere at which each of the spheres is going to touch the larger sphere. Prehaps it would be easier to start off by thinking in terms of circles then work up to spheres. If you have circles radius 1 and one circle radius 2 on which point of the smaller circles to the points meet. We have to find some sorta equality. The first way to do this that came to my mind was to find the length of the cord of the larger circle formed by the two points at which it meets the two smaller circles, and the distance between the two points on the smaller circles. Now, on a sheet of paper draw two circles, one big one and one small one. Now draw a line connecting the two centers, and youll notice that it crosses the point at which it intercepts. Were gonna use this to solve your problem. Now, imagine the two small circles are the bottom two circles lying on a flat line, and the large circle is resting on top. Now draw a perpentdicular to the flat line through each of the circles centers. This is where im going to be basing my angles from.

The length of the cord between the two circles will r * sin(x) * 2. Think about it, figure it out, and once youve got it procede.

The length between the two smaller circles will be 2 * (r - sin(y)). Remember were finding the difference between the full distance between the two circles centers and the points on the circle. Ok once youve got that.

remember how the line passed through the point at which the circles touched, well this means that x = y, think about it.

Ok, easy bit, 2 * sin(x) * 2 = 2 * (1-sin(x))
2sin(x)=1-sin(x)
2=1/sin(x)-1
1/3=sin(x)
x=asin(1/3)
uve got ur angle, and now u can solve.

Little bit harder for the sphere, uve got to find a triangle. I dont know why, but im opting to do this by area of the triangles.
now because the three spheres at the bottom will form an equilateral triangle, all the angles at the center of the big sphere will be the same, so its safe to say the length of one cord (if thats what you call them in spheres) will be equal to r * sin(x) * 3^.5
Ok, ill explain where i got that. I didnt want to use lots of trig funtions if it could be avoided, so i know that the radius of any circle in the sphere is equal to sin(x)r. now divide that circle up into a hexagon. Now use pythag to find the length of the cord which connects every second point of the hexagon, forming an equilateral triangle.
Ok, now the formula for the area of an equilateral triangle is b * .5b3^.5 = .5b^23^.5
now b = r * sin(x) * 3^.5
.5(r * sin(x) * 3^.5)^23^.5
.5r^2sin(x)^2*3^1.5
ok and for the small spheres, well, ive already figured out how to solve it so theres no more fun for me finishing this post, so ill leave it for you to solve. Do the same thing as I did for the circles.

Read full topic

item.title: Math
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

[quote=“Coolnoob55, post:1, topic:4158”]Just some problems needed for everyday life

Let a[sub]1[/sub], a[sub]2[/sub]… , be a sequence with the following properties.

Let a[sub]1[/sub] = 1 and a[sub]2n[/sub]= n * a[sub]n[/sub] for any positive integer n

What is the value of a[sub]2 100[/sub] Something like that, can’t seem to get it.[/quote]

I’m positive you’ve incorrectly typed this problem or that it is unsolvable. Currently the problem says that for any position in the sequence that is twice the position of another a[sub]2n[/sub], the position equals half its position times the value of the position of half its size. Which means you could only calculate numbers that were powers of 2 such as 64 or 128. Please try typing the question straight out of your homework.

If you meant it to say a[sub]n+1[/sub]= n * a[sub]n[/sub] then a[sub]2[/sub] = 1 * a[sub]1[/sub] = 1 * 1
Thus a[sub]n[/sub] = (n-1)! also known as factorial. Take out your calculator and multiply from 99 to 1 in this case to find out what a[sub]100[/sub] equals.[br][size=1]Posted at: July 08, 2006, 06:26:15 PM[/size][hr][quote=“Coolnoob55, post:1, topic:4158”]Three mutually tangent spheres of radius 1 rest on a horizontal plane. A sphere of radius 2 rests on them.

What is the distance from the plane to the top of the larger sphere?

Help is appreciated ;)[/quote]

I’m assuming this is just a trick of a question. It seems that they’re asking you what is the distance from a plane to the top of the sphere when the sphere is resting on top of circles. Since we know that circles have no depth, the distance between the bottom of the sphere and the plane is 0. Since the distance from out point on the outside of the sphere to its direct opposite on the sphere is the diameter, the distance from the top to the plane should be 4 units.

Read full topic
